noun.description: A body of people (typically twelve in number) sworn to give a verdict in a legal case on the basis of evidence submitted to them in court.
examples: the jury returned unanimous guilty verdicts

verb.description: Judge (an art or craft exhibition or exhibit)
examples: the exhibition was juried by a tapestry artist

adjective.description: (of a mast or other fitting) improvised or temporary.
examples: we need to get that jury rudder fixed

phrases: the jury is still out on whether self-regulation by doctors is adequate
Shock therapy economics did not save Argentina, and the jury is out on Russia.
But from the comments made by shareholders talking in groups after the meeting and the market performance since, it is clear the jury is out on the new strategy.

Danon's own admission that the jury is out on his mobile and wireless telephony target does little to convince the sceptics that he or the company can make in-roads into a sector it only recently abandoned.
I'd say the jury is out on whether we should fight it or not.
origin: Early 19th century: independent usage of the first element of early 17th-century jury-mast temporary mast, of uncertain origin (compare with jury-rigged).
